newsitem.title: CHINA: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - ASIA WATCHES RESCUE PACKAGE.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN DEBT MARKETS - ASIA WATCHES RESCUE PACKAGE.

text.p: The Thai rescue package drafted by regional central bankers was the main focus of Asian debt markets on Monday.
Activity was relatively muted as bankers waited to see how much their respective economies were committing to the package.
Asian central bankers and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) ultimately agreed to a US$16 billion rescue package.
The package includes contributions from Australia, Hong Kong, Singapore Malaysia, Indonesia, Korea, Japan and the IMF, and China is considering joining the rescue.
It is already the single largest loan package to a single country since the IMF and donors led by the United States made nearly US$40 billion available to Mexico in 1995.
Bankers said the size of the various contributions reflected the exposure of various countries, particularly Japan, whose banks have been major lenders to Thai banks.
"In terms of who has more at stake, it's pretty clear, Japan has more at stake," said a Tokyo-based economist at a US investment bank.
The package is seen as the first sign that Thai's currency woes may be ending, and its top banks may be in a position to raise medium-term cash again in U.S. dollars.
Currency and credit fears have paralysed parts of the market, with some issues either being pulled and repriced or else offered with special credit clauses.
In other news, an underwriting group has been formed for a unit of Cheung Kong Infrastructure Holdings Ltd.
The five-year facility has a margin of 39 basis points over the Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate.
It is divided into a HK$2.0 billiion term loan and a HK$1.8 billion revolving credit which converts into a term loan after 2-1/2 years.

In China, the Shanghai branch of China's biggest bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, will lend 500 million yuan (US$60 million) to a local electric company this year, according to reports from a Chinese news agency.
